titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Monday

I got bewildered this morning in the composition and wrote much which it will be necessary for me to expunge— I have already written about double the quantity that I ought to read, but not more than half what I propose—the task of retrenching is easy enough but mere garrulity will be promptly detected and generally despised— Into that I am falling and from which I must endeavour to extricate myself from to-morrow— The description of General Washington’s journey from Mount Vernon to
to New-York, would make a glowing picture by a skilful hand; but I have spoiled it. Mr T. B. Johnson paid us a morning visit— Between 1. and 3. I went and sat for my portrait to Mr S. M. Charles— Second walk in the Evening twilight— Mrs Hellen and her Son Walter spent the Evening here— Whist with Mr Smith, Mary and Walter.
2. IV:45. Tuesday

Rose with Idle disposition, and charcoal headache— My discourse drags heavily along— Call at the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions—left with him the Pension certificate of Mrs Margaretta Duffield to be exchanged for one of larger amount. Made enquiries concerning other claims— Deliverance Perry and Pincin, concerning which Mr Edwards promised to make report— Call at Lewis Johnson’s and left with him a packet received this morning from Mr John Otis of West Barnstable— Then Walk to the Capitol—enquired of Mr Burch for the authenticated copy of the Resolution of Thanks of the two houses of Congress to George W. La Fayette; and the family of the General, for their present of the Copy of his Writings, published by them— The Resolution engrossed was there, signed by the Secretary of the Senate, and the Clerk of the House; but neither by the Vice President nor by the Speaker— I was teazing the Clerk for an authenticated copy of this Resolution—but they had forgotten it, and now I must take and forward the Resolution upon the authentication of the Secretary and Clerk— In the library I found the Dauphin’s Edition of Cicero and the passage for which I was seeking—[“]Sed cum omnia ratione animoque lustraris, omnium societatum nulla est gravior, nulla carior, quam ea, quae cum republica est unicuique nostrum— Cari sunt parentes, cari liberi, propinqui, familiares, sed omnes omnium caritates patria una complexa est: pro qua quis bonus dubitet mortem oppetere, si ei sit profuturus?[”] De Officiis 1.17.— In the year 1787. when I was a Senior Sophister at Harvard University, a military mania seized upon the undergraduates, and the Senior and Junior Classes formed themselves into a company calling themselves the Marti Mercurian band— It was the revival of an old company which had borne that name during or preceding the revolutionary War, after which it had been discontinued, but was now reinstituted in the heat of belligerent fervour against the insurgents— The company reorganized itself, chose a Captain, Lieutenant, Ensign—Adjutant, Sergeants and Coporals—obtained a loan of fire-arms from the Castle—drilled—paraded—bustled; and asked permission to go with the party from Boston, which took Job Shattuck; which the College Government however declined to grant— Solomon Vose a Classmate of mine, no Scholar, but a fine handsome fellow six foot tall, was chosen Captain of this company; and my Cousin William Cranch was adjutant. I did not join them— When our Class was about to leave the University—the Chief Officers retired and their places were supplied by others chosen from the next Class The company had a ground parade, and Captain Vose on retiring from his command delivered to them a very handsome valedictory, as they were drawn up in the yard fronting Harvard Hall.— I was present as a Spectator, and was very much
much struck with the introduction into his Speech on this passage from the Offices—Cari sunt parentes—&c—for I had not then read the Offices and had never before heard the Sentence— It has never gone out of my memory since that day— At the library I read also in the Southern literary Messenger a severe review of Kirby’s Bridgewater Treatise on the Creation, and natural History of Insects— Second walk at evening twilight— My wife, Mrs Smith and Mary spent the Evening at Mr T. B. Johnson’s— Mr Winney came hear and made an offer of 5 dollars for Mrs Mary Jane Laurence’s Land Patent in Missouri of which I promised to inform her— Mrs Adams, Mrs Smith and Mary spent the Evening at Mr T. B. Johnson’s.
3. IV:30. Wednesday

I bewilder myself more and more every day with my discourse, and am getting to be much discouraged. I see the necessity of making the address appropriate to the occasion, and feel as if I was all the time approaching to my subject without reaching it— The merit of it should consist in being exactly suited to that day and to none other.— But here forlorn and lost I tread; with fainting steps and slow, where wilds immeasurably spread seem lengthening as I go.— Concentration of much matter into small compass should mark the composition—rapidity of narration—bold dashes of character—contrasted glances at the results of the Confederation compared with those of the Constitution, and conclusions pointing with clear foresight to futurity—that is what I want, and what I cannot obtain— When I reflect how trivial this matter is, of reading a short historical disquisition to a private Society, I am ashamed of making myself a Self-tormentor about it—but such is my nature; and I shall have no quiet of mind till it is over, and perhaps then less than ever.— I was occupied this day till past one, with my task, and then went and gave a sitting to Mr Charles for my Portrait— The tension of mind all the morning was so great that when the pressure was taken off, an exposition of sleep came over me, and I was dosing all the time of the sitting to Mr Charles— He told me that he had heard Stuart once painted such a sitter—asleep— Walk by Evening twilight, with my wife— Mrs Parris wife of the 2d. comptroller, and Mrs Grundy, wife of the Attorney General paid her a visit, and Mrs. Grundy left a card for me. I received a queer Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury about the two Smithsonian fund bills—Robbins’s and mine—a Letter from C. Hughes who has been very ill but has recovered, and is going again to Sweden—and Letters from West-Point and Waterville College for Addresses.
4. IV:30. Thursday

Morning visit from Dr Sewall, who wants my Letter of recommendation for his Lectures upon Phrenology— And I promised him a Letter, for Saturday Morning— In the progress of writing my discourse I wanted to make reference to the voyage of Captains Kendrick and Gray in the Columbia and Washington, as I thought from 1787. to 1790— I looked into Gales and Seaton’s collection of American State Papers, but found nothing there but Floyd’s Report upon the Oregon Territory, and he barely mentions his name once, and speaks of his Voyage as having been made in 1785— I went to the State Department, but Mr Forsyth, the Secretary was at the Presidents— I asked Mr Vail the Chief Clerk for Mr Ingraham’s Journal which was purchased I think when I was President and he brought it in four thin folio Volumes, the whole making not more than a pamphlet of 200 8vo. pages; and it is a journal, not of the voyage of the Columbia and Washington, but of a subsequent expedition in a vessel called the Hope which sailed from Boston in September 1791. and went to the Sandwich Islands and to Nootka sound in 1792. There is towards the close of the 4th. Volume a Letter from Robert Gray and Joseph Ingraham to the Spanish Commandant at Nootka Sound and a Letter from him to men, with reference to what had taken place two years before between the Spaniards and English at that place of which Gray and Ingraham say that they were witnesses, but I find nothing respecting the Columbia river— Ingraham’s journal is full of drawings; and of small maps of Islands and ledges of rocks, somewhat showy, but very indifferently executed, and there seems to be nothing of much value in the journal itself— Walks before and after dinner.
5. IV:15. Friday.

I am adverting to the measures of President Washington, and of the first Congress under the Constitution to restore the honour and prosperity of the Country. Still excursive yet anxious to combine all the matter of my argument to the Unity of my Discourse— I see that I ought to write it over again, but I have not the Time; and what is worse not the Patience— Mr Stanhope Prevost was here; a son of the late judge Prevost some time an informal agent appointed by President Monroe to several of the South-American Republics, and who died somewhere in the interior of Peru— The Son continues to reside at Lima, and after an absence of about 18 Months, on a visit to his friends and relatives in this Country, is about to return by the way of the Isthmus of Panama— He said he came to see me at the request of Mrs Stewart, to bear testimony to the extraordinary merit of Mr William Tudor while Consul, and diplomatic agent in Peru, which he did with the utmost satisfaction— That he had never known any other American abroad so universally a favourite as Mr Tudor, both with Americans and followers— He said Mrs Stewart had requested him to call on me to bear this testimony, because Mrs Tudor wished to make another application to Congress for some further allowance to her on account of
of her Son’s extraordinary merit— I called at the Bank of Washington, and then at the Office of the National Intelligencer where I saw Mr Gales— W. Parmenter has at last carried his re-election to Congress for the 4th Congressional District of Massachusetts by a majority of 9 votes— But the 6 members of the last Congress from Connecticut are all turned out, and an entire new delegation come in their stead—all whigs. Gales had a Letter somewhat extraordinary from George Evans which he read to me— He thinks that if Mr Fox could be recalled and Sir John Harvey commissioned with full Powers the boundary line question could be settled at once— Gales gave me also two copies of Mr Cushing’s Report upon the Oregon Territory made 4 last January in the Appendix to which there is precisely the information that I wanted respecting the voyage of the Ship Columbia, Captain Kendrick and Sloop Washington Captain Gray from 1787 to 1790. and their Discovery of the Columbia river in 1792 Second, or Evening twilight walk.— Letter to Dr Thomas Sewall.
6. IV. Saturday

In the discourse for the New York historical Society, I have come to the review of Washington’s administration of the foreign Affairs, and the subject opens upon me so that I know not when to stop— Britain, France, Spain, Portugal, Algiers, the French Revolution, and the Indians, how is it possible to touch upon these topics, without falling into garrulity? I thought I had finished with England this morning, and began upon Spain; but I was obliged to return back to England, and then found myself chin deep in the french revolution— My time and paper grow short, and all that I write is so dull, that I shall be puzzled not what to leave out but what to retain— The Algerine papers also wasted much of my time, and it was past two O’Clock went I went to Mr S. M. Charles the Painter’s chamber and gave him the third sitting for my portrait— A poor job— His colours are vermilion, Chremnitz, a mixture of white lead and silver, Yellow Ochre, Black ivory, ultramarine blue, made of lapis lazuli and madder lake— These are all mixed up with Oil— Mr Charles is ambitious to do well, but as yet hardly reaches mediocrity— After dinner I wrote a short Letter to Lewis and Pierce, and received one from J L. Edwards promising an increase of Pension for the heirs of Nancy Lewis— One from James C. Doane concerning the claim of Mrs Abigail Lincoln— One from Samuel Webb about Slavery— One from Robert M. Hartley, corresponding Secretary of the New-York Temperance Society, requesting me to deliver an Address before them at their Anniversary Meeting on the 9th. of next Month. Evening twilight walk observed Venus, Jupiter, Mars, Sirius and Procyon. Mrs Adams Mrs Smith and Mary, with the two children spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s.
7. V:15 Sunday

Lingering along in my discourse, with the difficulties with which Washington had to contend in his Administration. How shall I get out of the woods? Attended Morning worship at the Unitarian Church, and heard Joseph Pearce Cranch from Matthew 17.1. [“]And after six days Jesus taketh Peter James and John his brother, and bringeth them up into an high mountain apart. 2— And was transfigured before them, and his face did shine as the Sun, and his raiment was white as the light.”— There is a mystery about the scene of the Transfiguration: which it seems to be presumption to approach. I had never heard a preacher venture upon it before— But Mr Cranch treated it with much delicacy and proper reverence— The narrative states no particular motive for this premeditated manifestation of glory to three of the Apostles apart from the rest. It is remarkable that John who was one of the three chosen witnesses of this glory says nothing of it either in his gospel or in his epistles, or in his apocalypse. But Peter in his 2d. Epistle testifies to it— After dinner at St. Johns Church Mr Hawley read the service for the first Sunday after Easter and Bishop Doane preached from John 6.37—[“]him that cometh to me, I will in no wise cast out.” He said he preferred this for a text to the preceding half of the same verse, because that was supposed to contain the doctrine of predestined election and reprobation—, which had agitated the church for several centuries past and was like to do so for time to come. I went at half past 3. but the time of meeting was an hour later and I called at Mr T B Johnson, where Mary with her two children, and Mrs Frye and her Son Thomas B. J had been dining— After returning home from Church I took a short walk with my wife— The weather these four days has been at Summer heat and all the Peach and cherry trees are in full blossom
8. IV:15. Monday

I begin to fear that I have not given myself time and space enough for my historical discourse; and still more to apprehend that it will be insupportably tedious and dull. Going out this morning I met successively Christopher Hughes, Baron Marechal and Commodore Patterson— Then Mr Felix Grundy the Attorney General with Mr Gilpin the Solicitor of the Treasury—afterwards Mr Frye and lastly General Scott, just returned from his expedition eastward. I called at the War Department and left with Mr Poinsett a Declaration of W. Huntley to procure his warrant for Military Bounty Land. I read to him also part of a Letter from Mr James C Doane of Cohassett, relating to the Pension claim of Abigail Lincoln— I had also some conversation with Mr Grundy and afterwards with Mr Poinsett on the Smithsonian fund Bills
Bills— The debate in the Senate upon Robbins’s Bill is published in the National Intelligencer of this morning; and a debate between Great Cibber’s brazen brainless brothers at the gates of bedlam would be more rational and a debate between Jonathan Wild the great and Barrington of Botany Bay as honest as the discussion in this dignified body upon this munificent and magnificent bequest— Calhoun’s speeches on the subject are the very delirium of malignity— Grundy and Poinsett both spoke fair words— So did Woodbury when I went to him about it— But I almost despair of doing any thing effective with it— I left with the Commissioner of Pensions Mr Doane’s Letter respecting Abigail Lincoln’s Pension claim, and pressed him for a favourable decision upon it—he promised me a Report to-morrow. Returning home, I met almost at my door Mr M’Lellan who requested me to attend a meeting of the 2d Presbyterian Church at 1/2 past 4 this afternoon which I promised, and went accordingly— Mr Fowler has written him a Letter announcing his intention to leave them at the end of the present quarter— There were about 100 persons at the Meeting; about two thirds of them women— Mr M’Lellan had offered a Resolution that a Committee be appointed to wait on Mr Fowler, and request him to withdraw his Letter of resignation— And another that the members of the Society will do all in their power to increase his compensation— The first of these Resolutions was debated with much acrimony, but passed by a vote of 50 to 12 pew holders and communicants— The women voting as well as the men—the second resolution passed without opposition— A Committee of 9 were appointed. I excused myself from voting, though a pew holder, because I was not a member of the Church— Mr A. K. Parris was moderator, and Mr Grundy was there— Another Letter inviting the Society to send a delegate to the assembly of the Presbyterian Church. This Letter was laid on the table. The meeting was dissolved about six O’Clock, after which I took a twilight walk— Mr Cammach was here this morning, and told me he proposed to build a stable on my ground I told him I would think of it and give him an answer.
9. V:15. Tuesday.

I wrote so slowly this morning that with the time consumed by my visitors I could neither sit for my Portrait to Mr Charles, nor take my morning walk— Mr Wilcox was here wanting a loan of money to purchase a patent of a scythe or grass mower to take to the Western Country— But I told him I had not the means of accommodating him— I had also much conversation with him on the recent elections to Congress from the State of Connecticut
where the whole delegation has been changed; and on the prospects of the present administration, which are unpromising, but not desperate— Mr Christopher Hughes was also here, and shewed me the models of two bed steads of his invention, for which he has taken out Patents in Sweden, and proposes to take them out here— He was to dine this day with the President who gives a dinner of parade to General Scott.— Hughes has promised to dine with us to-morrow, and he goes in the afternoon Cars at half past 4 tomorrow—for Baltimore— He is to embark towards the close of this month at New-York, to return to his Post as Chargé d’Affaires at Stockholm— His son has passed through the Academy at West Point and is in the Army— He leaves his daughter with his Sister at Baltimore, and goes to solitary diplomacy at Stockholm— The disease with which he has been nearly two months confined is plethoric, and he will be hence compelled to live upon diet with the gods— He struggles to sustain his Spirits, but is obviously much depressed— I spoke to him about obtaining for me information concerning the observatory at Greenwich and the Astronomer royal which he promised to do— I took my evening twilight walk— Mr Smith did not come home to dinner, and sent a note to his wife this Evening that he was in the custody of the Marshal—on an order of the court that he should give new bail, on a new suit ordered and entered by the District Attorney F. S. Key— I gave C. Hughes the certificate Letter that he had requested; and this evening answered two Letters from Edgar B. Gaither, for a Committee of the Dialectic Society at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, inviting me to deliver an Address before them next June—which I decline.
10. V:15. Wednesday.

As I draw towards the close of my Discourse, and feel the necessity of compressing my thoughts, the labour becomes more irksome, and my distrust of my own work more distressing— I find on reading over parts of what I have written tiresome diffuseness, and multitudinous repetitions— Soon after noon I went and gave a fourth sitting for my Portrait to Mr Charles— Mr Hughes and Dr Thomas dined with us. Soon after 4. O’Clock, Hughes took leave of us, to return by the Railway Cars to Baltimore; whence he goes to embark at New-York on the 25th. of this Month for Liverpool— His gay and sprightly character, and inexhaustible Spirits are gone, but his kind and affectionate temper remain— After he and the Doctor were gone I finished my daily task, which I had not been able to complete before dinner— Miss Mary Cutts was here; but the Ladies were riding out, and she did not stay— In the evening Miss Wooster, Miss Williams, and Miss Smith three of the young Ladies teachers at Miss Breschard’s school were here— I took my twilight walk.
11. V:45. Thursday

Rose by broad daylight, and was occupied till 3. O’Clock P.M. upon my task— General Daniel Parker was here; and left for my perusal a small volume, called Passages from the Rembrancer of Christopher Marshall a private Diary kept at Philadelphia in 1774–5 and 6. now published by William Duane— Parker says that a recent publication of W. C. Rives has explained to him the Somerset of J. C. Calhoun, at the special Session of Congress in September 1837. he says that Genl. Scott has settled it in his mind that he is to be the next President— Mr T. B. Johnson was also here— Towards Evening there came Mr Charles W. Morgan, of New Bedford, asking for advice— He said he and his partners had for years past made yearly contracts to furnish Oil for the Lighthouses along the shores— The contracts stipulate payment by the Government on the 1st of April; and they have been so paid several successive years— This year the contract is for 94000 dollars—but when he came for payment it was refused by the Secretary of the Treasury, because the Law prohibits payment upon contracts in advance— The contracts are made by the 5th. Auditor Stephen Pleasonton; and it was his casually using the word “in advance” that startled the Secretary of the Treasury who would otherwise have paid the money as he had done before— Morgan told him that he would be very glad to abandon the contract which was a very unprofitable one; but Mr Woodbury advised him to consider whether if he abandoned the contract he would not be liable to a prosecution. Mr Woodbury had referred the case to the President who had said the Law must be observed— Mr Morgan said he thought it very hard that he should be held responsible for his stipulations in the contract, and the Government under no obligation to perform theirs; and he said Mr Woodbury had offered to take the opinion of the Attorney General in the case— I advised him to take the Secretary at his word— To require him to take a written opinion of the Attorney General, upon a written statement of the case— That in the Statement the facts should be included; that the same contract had been made several years in succession, and that Mr Woodbury had always made the payments till this year.— And to require specially the opinion of the Attorney General; whether, if the Government is not bound to payment at the day named in the contract, he can still be bound to execute it on his part— I did not think it could be considered as a payment in advance, as he must already be under responsibilities of payment for the supplies— And I advised him to tell Mr Woodbury that if while the
the Government refused payment as stipulated by their own Officer, and yet held him on pain of prosecution to the fulfilment of his part of the contract, he should petition Congress at their next Session, for indemnity and damages.— He said he would follow my advice— I had received a note from Mrs Stewart requesting me to call, on her mother this day; and I went as Evening twilight came on— It was to ask me, to write another Petition for her mother, for a further posthumous allowance from the Government, on her Son William’s Accounts— I said that if a new application could have any chance of success, it must be first introduced into the Senate— Mr George Evans, with a power of Attorney from Robert Gardner, an Executor of William Tudor’s Will received the money, upon the Act of Congress passed on Mrs Tudor’s petition— Mrs Stewart shewed me a passage in a Letter from Robert Gardner, professing a respect for my opinion, and adding that if I would say he was not bound by his Oath and bond as Executor to take the money he should think himself mistaken— I said I could give no opinion upon what his Oath and bond required of him, because I knew not what they were nor what was the Will—but that Congress had made the grant on the Petition of Mrs Tudor, and in the full persuasion that it would go to her benefit— That the Executors took not one step towards it—nor did I believe Congress would have passed the bill, on any application of theirs— Mrs Stewart wished me to write this as my opinion— A Mr Dunbar came in while I was there— An Irish Clergyman settled at New-York— He is attending on a Mr Stewart lying ill at Mr Aaron Vail’s.— I came home in the dark and a heavy rain.
12. V:30. Friday

Rain all Night and in showers almost all this day— I finished my Discourse to be read before the New-York historical Society on the 30th. of this Month— I have written it with a deep consciousness of decaying faculties, though with a bitter aversion to its being observed by others— It is too long by more than one half, and is full of repetitions—diffuse, garrulous and ill digested— Carelessly and hastily composed, requiring much pruning, and yet so knit together that I know not where to abridge— In my morning walk I called at Montandon’s shop— Dr Thomas told me he had procured from him a cask of ordinary claret wine—but he has none at present— The rain obliged me to shorten the walk— I took another by twilight during an interval of cessation by the rain— I wrote Letters to Dr Robert D. Pattison, President of Waterville College, Maine, declining to attend the Commencement at that Institution next August, and to deliver an Address there in the afternoon, for which I have received from him an invitation; and to Lewis and Pierce at Brooklyn to enclose a Notification from William Gordon Clerk of the Bounty Land Section of the War Department, to William Huntley, that a Land-warrant for 160 Acres, had issued in his favour, as a soldier in the last War with Great Britain— I enclosed yesterday to James C. Doane Cohasset a Pension Certificate for Mrs Abigail Lincoln
13. V:15. Saturday

Privilege of Speech in Parliament.— Strickland’s case—the first attempt to restrain the Freedom of Speech in the House of Commons— Hatsell 1. 85–125:136. Having finished yesterday the first draught of my historical Discourse, I wished this morning to continue my industrious occupation; and after wasting an hour or two in deliberating what I would turn to took up the Letter to the Petitioners, to be offered to the Editors of the National Intelligencer for publication— I soon found that I must review the Atherton Resolutions, but was so much interrupted that I could do only half a days work— But I ranged over the first volume of Hatsell and looked into Clarke and Force’s Documentary Collection preceding the Revolution— I gave a fifth sitting to Mr Charles, who is making a portrait of me different from any other and so like that it looks like a Caricature— He shewed me one of three Volumes of engravings from the Paintings of Sir Joshua Reynolds— They are in Copper plate and very indifferently executed; but he says he gave 200 dollars for the 3. This afternoon Mr Fendall called upon me— He had been consulted by Mrs Stewart only within two or three days, with a view to recover from Mr Gardner the Executor of William Tudor’s Will, the money granted by the late Act of Congress— But Fendall can do nothing about it now— Mrs Stewart and her Son Charles were also twice here this day— She came to press me for the Letter to her mother which I had promised to write—giving my opinion that the intention of the grant by Congress was to her. I promised again to write the Letter— I wrote to Joseph Blunt.
14. IV:15. Sunday.

Laboured closely upon the Letter to the Petitioners without finishing— Apprehensive that I shall have to write a second. At the Presbyterian Church this Morning, heard Mr Dwight, the Missionary who has resided several years at Constantinople— He preached from Matthew 13.43. “Who hath ears to hear, let him hear.” a very earnest and solemn discourse. Mr Dwight read a Letter from Mr Fowler, dated the 10th. in answer to the application from the Committee chosen last Monday to request him to withdraw his Letter announcing his intention to part from the Society— The present Letter is full of gratitude and good feeling; and he consents to withdraw his Letter of resignation— But he is obliged to go on a visit to the North, and will endeavour there to make arrangements for remaining pastor of the Congregation here— After dinner I attended alone at St. John’s Church where Mr Hawley read the service for the second Sunday after Easter, and preached from Hebrews 12.24 and to the blood of sprinkling that speaketh better things
things than that of Abel— After Sunset I walked as far as the Unitarian Church and back— Wrote the promised Letter to Mrs Tudor, and journalized all the Evening.
15. V:15. Monday

Continued writing on my Letter to the Petitioners, till I was ready to break down under the pressure— Went with my wife and Mary to return Mrs Felix Grundy’s visit, but she was not at home— Left Cards— Call on the Secretary of the Treasury with whom I found Mr Whitcomb the Commissioner of the General Land Office— I had a Treasury Note for 100 dollars dated 10. April 1838. at 5 per Cent interest— He referred me to the Bank of the Metropolis— I took it accordingly to the paying teller; who took out some Bank Bills to pay me— I said I would prefer to take it in gold— He said they did not pay treasury Notes in gold— I asked him in what they paid; he said in current Bank Bills— I asked if the Government did not pay their Notes in Specie? He said they had nothing to do with the Government— I said I had called on the Secretary of the Treasury who had referred me to that Bank for payment— He then said he could pay me in Sovereigns, and I took it in Sovereigns, of which he gave me 21. with six half dollars and 15 cents in silver change— I told him if he liked it better I would take it all in silver— He said they had less of that than of gold— I asked him at what rate he gave the Sovereigns—he said at four-eighty-five— I took this money thus for the sake of the experiment—and thus it was for a single hundred dollars and five for the interest— Positively refused payment in Specie in the first instance—and when I asked if the Government did not pay Specie, told that they had nothing to do with the Government— I told him I saw their Specie ran very low, and came off— There will be another suspension of Specie payments anon— After dinner I walked to the City Hall Square, and back— Pleasant conjunction of the Moon and Venus. Received a second Letter from Robert M. Hartley corresponding Secretary of the New-York City Temperance Society, inviting me to attend their general Meeting on the 9th. of May and deliver an address—answered and declined— Letter from Joseph L. Tillinghast at Providence R.I. asking from Mrs Mehetabel Mumford a return of her Petition answer— Letter from Elisha Whittlesey at New-York asking for Letters of Recommendation— Eyes inflamed— Evening gloomy. Charles T. Stewart called and took the Letter to Mrs Tudor, but I was out.
16. V:15. Tuesday

It seems as if I should never get through the Letter to the Petitioners, which I intended should not occupy two pages— I this morning rose able to write, which went I went to bed last Night I feared I should not be.— And I wrote stedfastly till near 2. P.M. Then called at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and told Mr Seaton I should to-morrow or the
the next day bring him a Letter to the Petitioners who entrusted me with their Petitions to be presented to H.R.U.S. to be published with the closing list, and which would cover from four to five columns of the paper— He appeared to be somewhat shy, and regretting that this subject was to be again agitated— I expected as much, and said if after reading my manuscript he should decline to publish it, I would simply notify the petitioners of the fact, and publish the Letter in another Newspaper.— And if so I should use it as an illustration of the suppression of the freedom of the press necessarily consequent of the suppression of the right of Petition, and freedom of Speech in the House. He thought there was another view of the Freedom of the Press which consisted of editorial independence in refusing to publish what ought not to be published— I thought there might be editorial independence in this but not much freedom of the press— He mentioned to me the alteration of the Atherton Resolutions, from the first set of them as agreed upon in the Caucus; and which Matthew L. Davis had disclosed in one of his Spy Letters— Rhett sent a copy of them as first agreed upon, to the Charleston Mercury, where they were published, differing considerably from those offered by Atherton. Seaton said they had published the two sets in parallel columns—but he could not find them— Mary dined abroad— I took an evening twilight walk, and to spare my eyes a little played Loo with my wife and grand-children— Johnson Hellen’s baby child dangerously ill.
17. V:15. Wednesday

Still toiling upon my Letter to the Petitioners without finishing and much occupied in searching up the report of a debate in the Senate of the United States on the 17th. of March 1834 upon the refusal to receive a preamble and Resolutions of a Meeting at York Pennsylvania, approving the removal of the deposites and against a recharter of the Bank of the United States— John Whipple, in a report to the Legislature of Rhode-Island, cited this, as a precedent authorising the refusal of a Legislative assembly to receive Petitions— After some search I found the report of the debate in the National Intelligencer— I found also in Hatsell the precedents in the British House of Commons cited by Mr Whipple.— This gentleman reported to the Legislature of Rhode Island an Argument upon the right of the Legislative Assemblies to refuse to receive Petitions— Ingenious and plausible— It entirely disconcerted the Rhode Island whigs—and took very well with the democrats. I am
undertaking to review it— I gave a sixth sitting to Mr Charles for my portrait, and walked at evening twilight to the western Market.
18 V. Thursday

At length I finished my first Letter to the Petitioners whose Petitions I presented to H.R.U.S. at the late Session of Congress— It is long, dull, and written in a hasty slovenly manner; and requires a second Letter which I have not now time to write— I returned by Cards the visits of Mr Jones the Minister from Texas, and of the Brazilian Chargé d’Affaires. Then went to the Capitol, and returned four Books which I had taken out of the Library. Then to the National Intelligencer Office, and left with Mr Gales the Letter which he promised should be published if at all next Tuesday. For Seaton had expressed some doubt whether they would publish it for fear of agitation— I asked Mr Gales to read it, and said I would call again to-morrow or the next day and if they declined the publication, I would take back the manuscript and publish it in some other paper— Seaton is going to-morrow with one of his daughters to Philadelphia— Gales was there last week to borrow money of the Bank of the United States, but he says the Spirit of that institution is gone since Mr Biddle resigned the Office of its President— Walter Hellen was here this afternoon and MrCoombs a son of Mr Philip Coombs of Bangor in the Evening— He is here to apply to the Post master General for a contract to supply India rubber Mail bags for the transportation of the Mails— A Mr Goodyear, has discovered a method of giving to India rubber the pliability and consistency of linen or cotton cloth, which makes it more suitable for the composition of Mail-bags than leather— Mr Coombs shewed us several samples of his India rubber cloths covering over linen, and one Apron of India rubber alone. I took my usual Evening twilight walk— Mrs Smith keeps her chamber since Mr Smith’s imprisonment, which is upon a prosecution by the Government; and from which he is not likely to be soon released— My time has been so much absorbed in writing that I can scarcely find any for reading. But I took up this day, and read some pages of a small volume— Narrative and Correspondence concerning the removal of the Deposites and occurrences connected therewith—by William J. Duane. There is a meekness of manner in this narrative, and in the correspondence on the part of the author which excites compassion, and contrasts with the crafty and scratching style of the papers written by Amos Kendall and signed by Andrew Jackson. The wire-workers throughout the whole transaction were Amos Kendall, and Reuben M. Whitney— Duane was a mere victim— M’Lane, Taney, Cass and Woodbury supple and submissive assentators. The ignorant vanity, and furious passions of Andrew Jackson the instruments of that most mischievous transaction.
19. V:15. Friday

The pressure upon my time is in no wise relieved. I wrote an answer to a Letter from Judge Hopkinson at Philadelphia received nearly three months since and one to James M. Mason at Winchester Virginia, to enclose Mr Henry Colmans second report of the Agriculture of Massachusetts, for a member of the Legislature of Virginia, for whom I had procured at Mr. Mason’s request during the late Session of Congress Mr Colman’s former Report— I received the second some days since from Governor Edward Everett.— I received yesterday a Letter from William Ellis of Dedham, relating to the Pension certificate of Lydia Rhoads which I lately sent him, and claiming for her an increase of Pension— And this morning a Letter from Jacob H. Loud, with the papers of a Pension claim for Grace Bisbee; and a claim of small increase for Lydia Keen— I called at the Pension Office, and left the papers of Grace Bisbee, who took minutes of the other claim, for I told him I was going away next week, and he promised me an early Report— Call at the Office of the National Intelligencer, but Mr Gales was not there— On Mr Charles, but he was engaged with another person— Mr Coombs and Mrs Frye dined with us— The Postmaster General approves of Mr Coombs’s India Rubber Mail bags— I snatched an hour to look into the first Volume of Sharon Turner’s History of the Anglo-Saxons, and found nothing but what seemed to me fabulous— There is something about Arthur whose time he fixes in the 6th. century, about 300 years before Alfred.— I am very ignorant even of the Romantic History of Arthur. I received from Mr Gales a bundle of papers, containing the Newspaper reports of the debates in H.R.U.S. on the Abolition Petitions presented by me in January and February 1837— They are now revising them for publication in the Register of Congressional debates—and wish me to revise my part in them. Evening twilight walk
20. V:30. Saturday.

I received from Mr Joseph Blunt an answer to my enquiries concerning the time and place for the delivery of the historical Dissertation before the New-York historical Society— The Place a large Church— The time Noon. The Duration from an hour to an hour and a half— I read over my discourse and selected from the beginning, the middle and the end three fragments, the delivery of which need not exceed an hour and a half, and is just about one third of what I have written. But whether my voice or the patience of the auditory will hold out for that time must remain for trial—
Coll. Thomas paid me a morning visit; full as he always is of political gossip, and the small caballing for place. He says that Mr Clay himself got up, and he believes wrote the anti-abolition petition from this District, upon which he made his anti-abolition speech at the last Session of Congress, and that its effect has been to demolish his last possible chance for the presidency— I said I supposed he expected to propitiate Southern votes by it— He said he would not get them— That his only prominent supporter at the South now was Mr Preston, but yesterday the most furious champion of nullification. It is indeed curious that Preston has avowed in a speech at a whig meeting and in a published Letter, that he was one of a small party of friends to whom Clay read his Anti-abolition speech before he delivered it in the Senate— Thomas said he had no doubt of the re-election of Mr Van Buren— I gave my seventh and last sitting for my Portrait to Mr Charles, who told me that he was forming his style upon the model of Sir Joshua Reynolds; but that he was a young man.— This is the thirty-fifth time that my likeness has been taken by Artists for Portrait, miniature, bust, or medal, and of the whole number Parker’s Miniature—Copley’s portrait in 1796 and Stewart’s head in 1825. with Persico’s bust now in the library room of Congress are the only representations of my face, satisfactory to myself. I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer to enquire if he had determined to publish my Letter to the Petitioners, or not—he said he had no doubt it would be published; but he had not had time to read it and had handed it over to his father. Mary-Louisa, went out with her drawing Master and several of his other pupils and female teachers at Miss Brechard’s school to the little falls to take sketchings from Nature—but she was not far enough advanced to take any herself— They were out till towards Sunset— Mrs Stewart was here, and left here Letters—one from her Son Charles, saying that his father had readily promised to relinquish his claim to any portion of the sum granted at the late Session of Congress for the relief of the legal representatives of William Tudor, one from George Evans to W. S. Coxe, proposing a Chancery suit at Boston, to settle the question; one from Coxe to Mrs Tudor enclosing this Letter, and an answer from Mrs Tudor to Coxe, positively declining to have recourse to any Court of Chancery upon the subject— And Mrs Tudor requested that I would call on her to morrow, after the Church service, for further consultation— I took my evening twilight walk— Mrs Thornton, with Mrs Talbot and her daughter were here, but I was in my chamber and did not see them— I answered a Letter from S. A. Foot, and began an answer to E. Price Greenleaf.
21. V. Sunday

Finished my Letter to E. Price Greenleaf. I was going to the Methodist Church at the Corner of the judiciary Square when just beyond the Roman Catholic church I met two women whom I did not know, one of whom said to me, are you going to hear Mr Codman— I answered yes— He does not preach to day, said she—we just come from that Church— I thanked the Lady for her information—turned back and went to the Presbyterian Church, where I heard a Mr Davis from New-York whose text
text was Genesis 5.24. “And Enoch, walked with God; and he was not; for God took him.” and he preached a very solemn Discourse upon this mysterious verse— Mr Davis exhorted his hearers to walk with God, and told them that although they could not flatter themselves to be exempted like Enoch from the pangs of death, Yet they would atchieve a Victory over Death more glorious than it would be to escape from him. After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read prayers for the 3d. Sunday after Easter, and discoursed upon Isaiah 55.3—“and I will make an everlasting covenant with you; even, the sure mercies of David”— Mr Higbee had preached in the morning— After Church I went over to Mrs Tudor’s, and found there a young man, named Ellis; a nephew of Mr Powhatan Ellis, who is going out as Minister Plenipotentiary to Mexico— This Gentleman is going with him and departs for New-York in the course of the present week— Mr Ellis soon went away, and Mrs Tudor and Mrs Stewart wanted advice how to procure the whole of the money granted by the late Congress for Mrs Tudor— Her two Sons, and the husbands of her two daughters are joint heirs with her of the personal assets of her Son William— I told them they must obtain relinquishments signed by each of the claimants, which upon being presented to the Executors will be vouchers for them to credit their account for the payment of the whole money to Mrs Tudor, and the Account would be approved and passed by the judge of probate— They wished me to put all this down in writing; and I promised to draw up a form of relinquishment, which I supposed would be valid as a voucher for the Executors— I called in the Evening at Mrs Hellen’s to ask Walter to go with me to hear Mr Cookman, but he said he was gone to Baltimore— Mr and Mrs Moody had just arrived from Mobile, Alabama.— Began a Letter to my Son—
22. V:15. Monday

Finished the Letter to my Son, but it absorbed the precious morning hours— I received two Letters from Lewis and Pierce, one enclosing Mrs Nancy Lewis’s Pension certificate increased from 230 to 480 dollars a year and again to be increased to 600—and the other requesting that the new certificate may be made payable in the city of New-York, instead of Trenton New Jersey, where the present certificate is payable— I called at the pension office, and left the certificate with Mr Edwards after endorsing on it and signed, as he required the request that the new certificate be made payable at New-York. I
I then called on Mr George Wood, late Treasurer of the Columbia College to enquire what prospect there was of the payment on the 1st. of next June of the payment of the year’s interest then to be payable on their debt to me.— He could not tell, but said they were making arrangements for the payment both of interest and principal of the debt in the course of the ensuing summer— But he referred me to Mr Anthony Rothwell the City collector of taxes, as the present Treasurer of the College— I proceeded to the City Hall, and visited first the Orphan’s Court, to ascertain where the judge would be there to receive my Statement Account of Guardianship of my two granddaughters Mary Louisa, and Georgiana Frances Adams— He said the judge would be there to-morrow at Noon. I then found Mr Rothwell who repeated in substance what had been told me by Mr Wood— That he could not tell whether the interest on the College debt to me, would be paid on the first of June, but that they hoped to pay the whole debt before next winter— I told him I should write to him on the subject— Next I went to the Franklin Insurance Office where I found a boy representing Mr James Hoban, now the Secretary of that Company, and who he said was at the Circuit Court now in Session— I enquired what prospect of a dividend. He said he had heard Mr Hoban say this morning it would be 10 per Cent. I received this afternoon, proof slips of the National Intelligencer of to-morrow, containing my Letter to the Petitioners, which I revised and sent back. In my evening twilight walk I met Dr Laurie standing at the gate in front of his house; and reminded him of his note of nearly three years standing to me. He said he would attend to it.— Mr Frye spent the Evening here, and thinks very little of Dr Laurie’s note; as little of that of Mr Barnard, and still less of that of William Brown— His note is ten years old. Those of Laurie and Barnard nearly three and three years outlaws a note debt in this District— Laurie is a Presbyterian Scotch Clergyman, receiving double pay as a Minister of the gospel and a Clerk in the War Department, deep in debt—blasted in credit, and preaching Salvation by Faith— Mr Frye has declined giving bail for W. S. Smith.
23. V:30. Tuesday

I wrote a Letter to Samuel Webb of Philadelphia; to return as he requested a Letter from him containing his plan for the emancipation of all the Slaves in this Union. Webb proposed to me to bring forward his plan, or to return his Letter, which I now do. I intended to write him a Letter of four lines, and wrote four pages, which consumed the morning. I wrote a Statement, to serve as an account of guardianship of my granddaughters Mary Louisa, and Georgiana Frances Adams which I took to the City Hall, and delivered to the Judge of the Orphan’s Court, by
by whom it was accepted— I went then to the Capitol and applied again at the Clerk’s Office of the House of Representatives for copies of the Resolution of thanks of both Houses of Congress to George W. La Fayette and the family of the late General, for the copy of his Memoirs and Writings which I presented to Congress for them last December. They had the 2. Copies engrossed on parchment, and Mr Burch told me he was going himself to embark in about ten days for France and offered to take my Letter to G. W. La Fayette which offer I accepted— I selected also several copies of the two Bills reported to both Houses of Congress— by me 16. Feby 1839. H.R.U.S. 1160 mine and 1161. A. Robbins’s—and the sheets of the Journal of the House to page 656. sheet 41. They promised to send me the remaining sheets and Index as they come out, to Quincy—and also the Report upon Indian Reservation Land Sales made to the House 20. Feby— Mr T. B. Johnson was here this forenoon— Much of my time was consumed in filing Letters; and a fruitless search for those of Dr Laurie and Barnard, with their Notes.— In my twilight Evening walk as I was passing by Mrs Tudor’s she had me called in, and with Mrs. Stewart, asked me for the form of relinquishment to be signed by her children coheirs with her, of her Son William’s personal Estate, of their claims to equal portions of the late grant by Congress, and also for a Letter expressing my opinion which I promised to send her to-morrow— But it seems there also Creditor claims and Mr Gardner has written to Nathaniel Amory who is one of them—to make terms with them— Mrs Tudor relies on a decision of the Supreme Court U.S. at their late Session, that creditor claims cannot intercept such grants— She is much offended at a Letter from George Evans to W. S. Coxe, in which he repeatedly advises what Mrs T. should do.— I have a return of catarrhal cough
24. V. Wednesday.

Sonnet to Georgiana Frances Adams— The Casket. Wrote a Letter to Mrs Tudor, with a form of relinquishment for her children to sign if they think fit, to ensure to her the whole benefit of the grant in the late Act of Congress.— All the rest of the morning was swallowed up, in assorting and filing Letters received since my arrival here the 28th. of last November—a task still left incomplete Mr Rush paid me a long morning visit, and I had much conversation with him concerning the Smithsonian bequest— I told him what had been done at the late Session of Congress, and gave him copies of my Bill, and of A. Robbins’s— He said that the reason why the notice from the Court of Chancery did not call for illegitimate children of Hungerford was because that portion of the bequest was by the Law of England null and void— And that the pretensions of the two claimants who
who appeared after he had obtained the money, were not only unfounded but absurd— He said he was now here to dispose of some house lots which he owns in the city, and for which he had received offers— I called at Mrs Tudor’s house, and left my Letter to her, with the form of a relinquishment and assignment— Also at Mr T. B. Johnson’s to take leave— Found Mrs Smith there; and she dined with her brother— I wrote to Mr Jacob H. Loud at Plymouth, and enclosed the Pension Certificate of Grace Bisbee, with an extract from J. L. Edwards’s Letter to me respecting the claim of Lydia Keen: and to William Ellis at Dedham, with an extract from Edwards’s Letter concerning the new certificate for Lydia Rhoads— Evening walk with my wife; and we called and took leave of Mrs Madison— The Intelligencer, from the Baltimore Newspapers announce the sudden death yesterday of Samuel Smith in the 87th. year of his age— One of the last remnants of our revolutionary War— The Intelligencer of yesterday contained also the closing List of Petitions presented by me at the recent Session of Congress, and my first Letter to the Petitioners.
25. V. Thursday

The pressure upon my time as that for my departure approaches becomes excruciating— So much to do at the last moment—and after all so much left undone— Among the felicities of Washington’s Life is the unity of the two great objects which he had to pursue— First the War of Independence, and secondly the Establishment of the Constitution of the United States— There is the unity of a Grecian Drama in both of them. A Tragedy and a Comedy— No reputation of a great man, can be acquired, but by the accomplishment of some great object— But perhaps Fortune is the great furnisher of occasions.— The Revolutionary age and the Constituent age were the times for great men— The administrative age is an age of small men, and small things— I wrote this morning to George W. La Fayette and enclosed to him the authenticated copy of the Resolution of thanks of the two houses of Congress to him and the surviving family of the General for the copy of his writings and Memoirs presented by them for the library of Congress. I enclosed also to Lewis and Pierce at Brooklyn Long Island the Pension Certificate of Mrs Nancy Lewis, increased to 600 dollars a year I called at the Office of the Secretary of War; but he, and all the other heads of Departments, and the President were gone to attend the funeral of General Samuel Smith.— I then called at Bowen the Tailor’s shop, and paid an old bill for I. H. A. Then at the Library of Congress and returned all the Books with which I was charged except the 10th. Volume of Peters’s Reports which I could not find— I gave the packet for G. W. Lafayette to Mr Burch, and bespoke the sheets of the Journal not yet printed, and the Index to be sent to me at Quincy— I had written a dunning Letter to Mr Barnard, and he had answered that he would call on me at 6. this Evening— He afterwards sent me an apologetic Letter, with promises to pay hereafter— I wrote also to Mr Anthony Rothwell, Treasurer of the
the Columbian College, and enclosed to him a note upon interest to be signed by him on the first of June, unless the interest payable on that day should be punctually paid. Towards Evening Mr Leonard Hammond of Rochester came and made a statement of a case according to which he has been greatly wronged on a contract to build a light house at the Southwest pass of the Mississippi— And he said Mr Pleasonton would not hear him— I promised to go with him to morrow to the Secretary of the Treasury— I called upon Richard Smith one of the Executors of Dr Huntt with the account of his House-rent from 1. Jany to 1. Novr 1838— He said it was correct, but must be passed before the Orphan’s Court to authorize him to pay it— Evening much harrassed.
